posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
For folks experimenting with GTSAM for pose estimation:  

I contributed some factors to the project, and I’d like your feedback.  

One of them, “PlanarProjectionFactor1,” estimates Pose2d given constant landmarks, camera calibration and offset. The use case here is “smoothing,” e.g., using one of the Fixed Lag Smoother classes. Another, “PlanarProjectionFactor3,” uses constant landmarks to estimate pose, calibration, and offset simultaneously—it’s great for automatic camera calibration. There’s also an SFM factor, but since our landmarks are fixed, it’s not as useful.  

Anyway, I’d like these to be generally useful to FRC teams, so please comment on this PR!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
GTSAM implements the "Factor Graph" approach to estimation. The general idea is to decompose the global estimation problem into local terms, known as factors, representing residuals such as camera re-projection error. These factors are iteratively solved to form a sparse nonlinear system. When errors are Gaussian, this method serves as a maximum-likelihood estimator.

A distinctive feature of this estimator is its optimization over factor residuals in measurement space, for example, in camera pixels. Today, GTSAM specifies a pose-isotropic uncertainty for camera-derived pose estimates, which is incorrect. The system addresses challenges in robotics and computer vision, employing C++ with Python wrappers, notably utilized on Raspberry Pi for FIRST Robotics Competition applications. Additionally, GTSAM has contributed factors addressing odometry, bearing to targets, and various geometric entities like 2D and 3D poses, accommodating camera distortions. While primarily suited for complex scenarios like airborne SLAM, it effectively handles more modest problems encountered in FIRST Robotics Competition, leveraging state-of-the-art techniques.

link_counts.title: GitHub - borglab/gtsam: GTSAM is a library of C++ classes that implement smoothing and mapping (SAM) in robotics and vision, using factor graphs and Bayes networks as the underlying computing paradigm rather than sparse matrices.
Reducing the uncertainty about the uncertainties, part 1: Linear and nonlinear | GTSAM

posts.name: Matthew Milunic
posts.cooked: Thank you so much for making this! I’ve been looking into GTSAM, and so far it seems pretty cool. I managed to make a factor for Swerve/Mechanum/Tank odometry + Slip Estimation along with a Gyro factor, but I have no idea how like cameras and their different calibration matrixes work, so thanks for this massive contribution! As soon as I get it a little more polished I plan on posting on Chief Delphi.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
sounds good. I’m curious how you implemented the slip estimator. Having a real tire model integrated would be impressive. Our design documentation provides detailed insights into our system’s functionality, although it may not fully reflect reality. The associated codebase, available on GitHub, includes implementations of both the localizer and calibrator components. Nearby tests demonstrate the full system in action.

We didn’t utilize this approach during the competition this year. Instead, we developed more effective methods for distortion and offset calibration, enhanced our camera hardware, and achieved highly accurate pose estimates—even with our simpler fusor setup.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Oh whoops, ok, fixed. Reading it again after a few months, it talks a lot about the protocol between the pose estimator node and the RoboRio: the complexity of so many node types is partly why we didn’t end up using any of it. In 2027 we’ll just run this on the main controller.

posts.name: Matthew Milunic
posts.cooked:
I was conducting research on papers when I discovered a straightforward yet effective method to address wheel slip. By converting a change in position into a continuous movement (using logmap) relative to the wheel, I could calculate an error between the expected movement (based on odometry) and the actual measured movement minus the wheel slip.  

This approach involves two main factors:  
1. One factor estimates wheel slip based on robot pose and wheel odometry, assuming the error follows a Gaussian distribution due to encoder variance and wheel diameter inconsistencies.  
2. Another factor uses a robust noise model (Welsch M-Estimator) to handle outliers caused by wheel slippage, particularly when the wheel is moving purely laterally.  

By applying this method to all four wheels, I achieved consistent results. In summary, I addressed wheel slippage by modeling it as a variable with a robust noise model, allowing reliable estimation even when the wheel slips excessively.

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
The text is:

@truher I'm looking at adding a variant of this factor for camera extrinsic calibration with tags at unknown poses. I want (world to tag origin, Pose3), (world to body, Pose2), and (body to camera, Pose3) unknown, with (camera calibration, Cal3) known.

It looks like as PlanarProjectionFactor is currently written, this would require that either the landmark pose be an Expression, or modifying PlanarProjectionFactor to deal with tag origin → tag corner transforms. Have yall thought about how we might approach implementing this?

**Cleaned version:** @truher I'm exploring adding a variant of this factor for camera extrinsic calibration involving tags at unknown poses. Specifically, I aim to handle cases where (world to tag origin, Pose3), (world to body, Pose2), and (body to camera, Pose3) are unknown, while assuming (camera calibration, Cal3) is known. Regarding PlanarProjectionFactor, it appears current implementation requires either the landmark pose to be an Expression or modifications to address tag origin-to-tag-corner transformations. Do any of you have thoughts on how we might proceed with this?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: I think you're describing exactly ProjectionFactorPPP except with Pose2 instead of Pose3 as the POSE parameter, so maybe it would just work if you added the wrap to gtsam_unstable.i?

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: ProjectionFactorPPP allows encoding information about the 4 tag corners being exactly ±3in from tag N’s origin. Since the landmark position is a Pose3, expressions cannot be used directly.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: Each landmark is represented as a Point3, allowing independent handling for fixed landmarks but complicating the process for dynamic ones. It's unclear what the optimal approach would be. One possibility involves using a factor per corner with links to the tag center pose, though this may increase computational complexity. Last year, I prototyped similar functionality using Python custom factors, though I noted their slowness. For further assistance, consider reaching out to Prof. Dellaert through the GTSAM users group.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: We received a response mentioning "easyslam," a project with factors, unit tests, and example code available on GitHub. The contributor suggests sharing the code by creating a pull request in GTSAM's unstable branch under easyslam. They are open to collaboration and offer assistance with implementation. Additionally, we found documentation related to easyslam at [this link](https://repository.gatech.edu/server/api/core/bitstreams/3d97af7d-a98c-42e4-adc3-462b46ee0d60/content). What do you think?

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Good find! I ftr have sent a join request to the Google Group which is still pending, or I’d chime in there. Looks like easyslam is exactly what we want. I wasn’t able to find the code for it linked in the paper or in GitHub—were you?
